title: CHIME/Slow overview and pilot survey: A new backend to search for second-duration radio transients with the CHIME telescope
summary: We present an overview of CHIME/Slow, a real-time transient search backend under development to search for second-duration radio transients using the CHIME telescope, and results obtained from a pilot survey carried out using the prototype version of the search pipeline. The prototype CHIME/Slow pipeline was tested on archival data obtained in December 2022, January 2023 and February 2023 with a total on-sky time of 17 days with an instantaneous Field of View (FoV) of $\sim$13 deg$^2$ . In this pilot survey, we detected nine bursts, one from a new non-repeating source and eight from the known hyperactive repeating source FRB 20220912A. Out of these nine bursts, two bursts from the repeater were not detected by CHIME/FRB, while the non-repeater was detected in the side-lobe of a beam in the CHIME/FRB exhibiting shorter pulse width and narrower bandwidth compared to the CHIME/Slow detection. Here we report properties of the bursts, discuss the sensitivity and completeness of the current version of the CHIME/Slow pipeline, and outline future development to improve its performance. Finally, based on these results, we report the all-sky rate (95% credible region) of radio transients with pulse widths between 16 ms to 5 s, fluence above 5 Jy ms and observing frequency of 600 MHz to be between 184 and 4556 bursts sky$^{-1}$ day$^{-1}$.

AI.tldr: CHIME/Slow's pilot survey detected nine radio bursts, including one from a new non-repeating source and eight from FRB 20220912A. It established all-sky rates for specific transient parameters.
AI.motivation: To develop and test a real-time backend (CHIME/Slow) for detecting second-duration radio transients and assess its sensitivity and completeness.
AI.method: Analysed archival CHIME data from Dec 2022-Feb 2023 (17 days) using the prototype pipeline, detecting bursts and comparing results with CHIME/FRB data.
AI.result: Detected nine bursts, two undetected by CHIME/FRB, and calculated an all-sky rate of 184-4556 bursts per sky-day for specific parameters.
AI.conclusion: CHIME/Slow shows promise for detecting faint or侧 lobe transients; future improvements will enhance its performance in transient astronomy.

title: Are black hole spins truly near-zero?
summary:
The fourth gravitational-wave transient catalog, GWTC-4.0, reports 153 binary black hole mergers with false-alarm rates $<1,\mathrm{yr}^{-1}$. Chirp masses are typically measured well, with the smallest fractional uncertainty being $2%$ at the $90%$ credible level. Spins, on the other hand, are poorly constrained: the median of the best-measured spin component of the population, the effective spin, is $χ_{\rm eff}=0.04$, with a typical $90%$ credible uncertainty of $Δχ_{\rm eff}=0.44$. The large majority -- $90%$ of the observed black holes -- are consistent with spin magnitudes $χ<0.57$ and are weakly aligned with the orbits. At $90%$ credibility, the peaks of the inferred posteriors for spin magnitude are found to lie in the range $0.01$--$0.23$.
  We show that this ``near-zero spins'' conclusion may be prior-driven, and that uniform-in-magnitude spin priors lead to under-exploration of the moderate-to-high spin region of parameter space. Adopting a physically agnostic prior that is uniform in spin-vector configuration space (i.e., spin states uniform within a unit sphere) yields similar constraints on $χ_{\rm eff}$, but substantially different spin-magnitude inferences than GWTC-4.0. The resulting shift in spins directly impacts tests of general relativity, constraints on near-extremal Kerr remnants, and astrophysical conclusions, including diagnostics of formation channels and hierarchical growth. In short, the data do not require vanishing spins -- the prior does, and accounting for this is essential for robust GR tests and population inferences.

AI.tldr: The GWTC-4.0 catalog reveals 153 binary black hole mergers with poorly constrained spins, mostly consistent with near-zero orientation and magnitude. The choice of spin priors significantly affects results, suggesting that prior assumptions, not just data, drive the conclusion of low spin values.
AI.motivation: To investigate how different spin priors impact the inferred properties of binary black hole mergers in GWTC-4.0 and their implications for tests of general relativity and astrophysical interpretations.
AI.method: Compare results from uniform-in-magnitude spin priors (used in GWTC-4.0) to a physically agnostic prior uniform in spin-vector configuration space. Analyze posterior distributions of spin parameters and their effects on gravitational theory and astrophysical conclusions.
AI.result: Near-zero spin inferences may stem from prior selection rather than data. A different prior leads to broader spin magnitude distributions, altering constraints on spins without changing $χ_{m eff}$ much. This affects conclusions about extremal black holes and merger origins.
AI.conclusion: Spin prior choice critically influences results; reliance on uniform-in-magnitude priors may bias conclusions. Robust analyses must account for prior dependence to ensure reliable tests of GR and astrophysical models.

title: Ballistic Surfing Acceleration as a Coherent Mechanism for Electron Acceleration in Galaxy Cluster Shocks
comment: 10 pages, 4 figures, submitted to Physical Review D
summary: Radio relics in merging galaxy clusters are widely interpreted as synchrotron emission from relativistic electrons accelerated at large-scale shocks. However, the efficiency of diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) is expected to be reduced in the low-Mach-number, weakly turbulent environments characteristic of cluster merger shocks, and recent results suggest that DSA itself may not constitute a viable physical mechanism. In this work, we investigate ballistic surfing acceleration (BSA) as an electrodynamically grounded mechanism for electron energization that does not rely on prescribed diffusion coefficients. We formulate BSA under typical cluster shock conditions and derive the balance between coherent acceleration by the shock convection electric field and radiative losses due to synchrotron and inverse-Compton cooling. This balance determines both the maximum electron energy and the resulting steady-state spectrum. By forward-modeling the associated synchrotron emission and comparing it with integrated radio observations of the Sausage and Toothbrush relics, we find that the observed spectral curvature and high-frequency steepening can be reproduced when only a very small fraction ($\sim 10^{-9} - 10^{-8}$) of the available BSA acceleration capacity contributes to systematic electron energization. Despite this extremely small efficiency, it is sufficient to accelerate electrons to Lorentz factors $γ\sim 10^4 - 10^5$ under cluster conditions. These results suggest that radio relics provide a promising astrophysical laboratory for probing coherent acceleration, and that the BSA framework may account for the production of relativistic electrons in cluster shocks.

AI.tldr: The study investigates the viability of ballistic surfing acceleration (BSA) over diffusive shock acceleration (DSA) for explaining radio relics in galaxy clusters, showing that BSA can account for observed synchrotron emission with low efficiency yet high electron energies.
AI.motivation: To address the inefficiency of DSA in low Mach number cluster shocks and explore an alternative mechanism (BSA) that doesn't rely on diffusion assumptions.
AI.method: Formulated BSA under cluster shock conditions, derived energy balance equations considering radiative losses, and modeled synchrotron emission against Sausage and Toothbrush relic observations.
AI.result: BSA reproduces observed spectral features using ~1e-9 to 1e-8 of available acceleration capacity, accelerating electrons to γ~1e4-1e5 despite low efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Radio relics are a viable laboratory for studying coherent acceleration, and BSA may explain relativistic electron production in cluster shocks more effectively than DSA.

title: Meson Form Factors
comment: 8 pages, article for the Encyclopedia of Particle Physics
summary: We give an introduction to and a short overview of light meson form factors. We first discuss the classical picture and how it then fits in with amplitudes in quantum field theory. We give a short overview of the main theoretical methods and then discuss pion, kaon, eta and eta' form factors.

AI.tldr: The paper provides an introduction to light meson form factors, discussing their classical foundations, integration into quantum field theory amplitudes, key theoretical methods, and specific form factors for pions, kaons, and eta/eta' mesons.
AI.motivation: To establish foundational understanding of light meson form factors for theoretical frameworks and experimental predictions in particle physics, bridging classical concepts with modern QFT approaches.
AI.method: The authors employ a comprehensive review methodology, synthesizing classical physics insights with quantum field theory formalism. They analyze established theoretical approaches and present case studies on specific meson form factors.
AI.result: A structured overview of light meson form factors is delivered, highlighting connections between classical models and quantum descriptions, as well as comparing theoretical predictions for different mesons (pion, kaon, eta/eta').
AI.conclusion: The study underscores the importance of meson form factors in probing QCD dynamics at non-perturbative regimes and guides future research directions for more precise theoretical models and experiments.

title: Observations of Binary Stars with the 1.3-m Devasthal Fast Optical Telescope Using Speckle Interferometry: An Attempt
comment: Submitted to BINA Conference-Proceedings. Comments are welcome
summary: We present a feasibility study exploring the implementation of optical interferometry and speckle techniques with the 1.3-m Devasthal Fast Optical Telescope (DFOT) at ARIES, which is currently dedicated to photometric observations. Using the sCMOS camera as the DFOT backend, we perform interferometric speckle observations of several binary stars. Standard Speckle Interferometry (SI) algorithms are applied to analyze the recorded data. While this study does not aim to achieve the diffraction limit of DFOT or address a full science-driven resolution case, it serves as a crucial testbed for instrumentation, data acquisition, and analysis of Speckles with DFOT. Notably, we successfully identify and correct tracking-related positional errors in the observed binary systems, demonstrating the viability of the approach. These results provide strong motivation for more systematic observations and future implementation of optical interferometry techniques at meter-class telescopes.

AI.tldr: This study demonstrates the feasibility of using optical interferometry and speckle techniques with the DFOT telescope, successfully addressing tracking errors and paving the way for future systematic observations.
AI.motivation: To explore the potential of repurposing DFOT for interferometric observations and validate the instrument's capability beyond photometry, establishing a testbed for future high-resolution studies.
AI.method: The team used DFOT's sCMOS camera for speckle observations of binary stars, applied standard SI algorithms, and corrected tracking-related positional errors in the data analysis.
AI.result: Successful identification and correction of tracking errors, proving the viability of interferometric techniques with DFOT, though diffraction limit and full science resolution weren't achieved.
AI.conclusion: The study confirms DFOT's adaptability for interferometry, encouraging further systematic observations and broader adoption of optical interferometry in meter-class telescopes.

title: Scalar field coupled to boundary in non-metricity: a new avenue towards dark energy
summary: While conformal transformations in metric scalar-tensor theories recover General Relativity, this feature is notably absent in standard non-metricity-based theories. We demonstrate that by introducing the boundary term C, a non-metricity scalar-tensor theory can recover Symmetric Teleparallel Equivalent of General Relativity (STEGR) in the Einstein frame. Motivated by this, we propose a novel gravity model where a scalar field couples nonminimally to both the non-metricity scalar Q and the boundary term C. We focus in the cosmological scenario where we present the covariant formulation and a unified autonomous system framework that treats generic affine-connection choices, including coincident and non-coincident gauges, on an equal footing. Our dynamical analysis across three connection branches reveals standard thermal histories and stable de Sitter attractors. These results show that boundary-term couplings provide a well-posed, geometrically flexible route to addressing late-time cosmic acceleration.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a new non-metricity-based scalar-tensor theory with a scalar field coupled to both non-metricity scalar Q and boundary term C, enabling recovery of STEGR in the Einstein frame. It develops a covariant cosmological framework for analyzing different affine connections, showing viable thermal histories and stable de Sitter attractors that could explain cosmic acceleration.
AI.motivation: To address the limitation of non-metricity theories in recovering GR via conformal transformations and to explore geometrically flexible methods for explaining late-time cosmic acceleration using boundary term couplings.
AI.method: Introduced a novel non-minimal coupling between a scalar field and both Q and C in non-metricity theories. Developed a covariant cosmological formulation with an autonomous system framework accommodating various affine connections (coincident/non-coincident gauges) for dynamical analysis across three connection branches.
AI.result: Revealed viable cosmological dynamics including standard thermal expansion and stable de Sitter phase attractors, demonstrating that boundary term couplings offer a well-posed geometric framework to address cosmic acceleration without fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: Boundary-term couplings in scalar-tensor theories provide a viable and geometrically versatile path to modeling cosmic acceleration, maintaining theoretical consistency while extending the applicability of non-metricity-based gravity models.

title: X-ray line diagnostics of the multi-phase gas in the Centaurus cluster core with XRISM/Resolve
summary: We report the multi-temperature structure of the intracluster medium (ICM) in the Centaurus cluster core observed with XRISM/Resolve. Thanks to its high energy resolution, Resolve enables us to measure fine structures of highly ionized emission lines from Si to Fe and to directly determine the excitation temperature and the ionization temperature from the emission line ratio diagnostics. The observed spectrum in the Centaurus core is well-represented by a double-temperature thermal plasma at collisional ionization equilibrium state rather than an isothermal one. The line ratio diagnostics also support this biphasic temperature structure. Particularly, the observed line ratios show a trend of increasing ionization temperature with atomic mass, while the ionization and excitation temperatures of Fe show nearly the same temperature. The resultant line ratios, which are well-represented by the two temperatures ICM, ~ 1.6 and ~ 3 keV, are also fairly consistent with the expected numbers when assuming the radial single-temperature ICM was projected in the cluster core along the line of sight. Due to the limited low-energy sensitivity of the Resolve with the gate valve closed, we investigated the effect of the cool component using the XMM-Newton/RGS spectrum, but it ultimately did not affect our results. The observed flux ratio between the Fe XXV He alpha resonance and forbidden lines shows an about 20% reduction, suggesting the presence of resonant scattering.

AI.tldr: The study reveals a double-temperature structure in the Centaurus cluster's core using XRISM/Resolve data, showing temperatures of ~1.6 and ~3 keV, with Fe ionization and excitation temperatures aligning. Resonant scattering influences Fe line ratios.
AI.motivation: Investigate the ICM's multi-temperature structure in the Centaurus cluster core to understand its thermal state and dynamics.
AI.method: Used XRISM/Resolve's high-resolution spectra to analyze emission line ratios from Si to Fe ions, confirming a two-temperature model. Cross-validated with XMM-Newton/RGS data to account for cool components.
AI.result: Core ICM is best fit by a double-temperature plasma (~1.6 and 3 keV) instead of isothermal. Fe ionization/excitation temps match, while ionization temps increase with atomic mass. Resonant scattering explains reduced Fe line flux ratios.
AI.conclusion: The Centaurus cluster core has a stable biphasic thermal structure, challenging isothermal assumptions. Resonant scattering affects Fe line diagnostics, highlighting the need for multi-instrument analysis.

title: Big Bang Nucleosynthesis and the Neutrino-Extended Standard Model Effective Field Theory
summary: We study the impact of light GeV-scale heavy neutral leptons (HNLs) on Big Bang nucleosynthesis (BBN) in the neutrino-extended Standard Model Effective Field Theory ($ν$SMEFT). We show that, based on very general considerations, BBN constraints complement laboratory searches at colliders, beam dumps, and neutrinoless double beta decay, by providing an upper bound on the cut-off scale of the effective field theory for HNL masses above $\sim$100 MeV. We identify target regions for future laboratory probes of the $ν$SMEFT parameter space that is bounded from above and below.

AI.tldr: The paper examines how light GeV-scale heavy neutral leptons (HNLs) affect Big Bang nucleosynthesis (BBN) within the neutrino-extended Standard Model Effective Field Theory (νSMEFT). It finds that BBN constraints add an upper bound on the EFT cutoff for HNL masses above ~100 MeV, complementing existing lab searches and guiding future experimental targets.
AI.motivation: To understand the interplay between particle physics models like HNLs and cosmological processes like BBN, and to explore how observational constraints from BBN can provide complementary limits on beyond Standard Model parameters when combined with laboratory experiments.
AI.method: The authors use νSMEFT framework to model HNL interactions, analyze BBN conditions, and derive constraints on the EFT cutoff scale based on HNL masses. They compare these with existing laboratory constraints.
AI.result: BBN places an upper bound on the νSMEFT cutoff for HNL masses >100 MeV, creating a constrained parameter space that future experiments (colliders, beam dumps, neutrinoless double beta decay) can target.
AI.conclusion: BBN provides essential upper limits on effective field theory parameters beyond what laboratory experiments can offer, guiding the design of future particle physics experiments to probe νSMEFT parameter regions bounded both above and below.

title: Statements of Current States of the Art for Key non-Coronagraphic Technologies for HWO
summary: In preparation for development of both key technologies and instrument concept studies to use those technologies, the Habitable Worlds Observatory Technology Maturation Project Office at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center has compiled a series of statements of state of the art for those same key technologies. These statements are being provided to the public as exemplars and suggestions for possible future collaboration for those same instrument concept studies, but without mandate, to enable proposing teams to be able to find the technical solutions they need to field a compelling proposal. This information resides in the public domain and is presented without prejudice.

AI.tldr: The Habitable Worlds Observatory Technology Maturation Project Office at NASA Goddard has compiled statements outlining current state-of-the-art technologies to aid in developing key technologies and instrument concepts. These resources are publicly available to encourage collaboration and support proposing teams in creating compelling missions.
AI.motivation: To foster innovation and collaboration by providing transparent access to current technological capabilities, enabling teams to develop robust mission proposals for studying habitable worlds.
AI.method: Compilation of state-of-the-art technology descriptions into publicly accessible documents, serving as references and collaboration catalysts for future instrument concept studies.
AI.result: Publicly available technical resources that guide and inform the development of space mission proposals focused on habitable worlds research.
AI.conclusion: The initiative promotes open science and collaborative problem-solving, ensuring proposing teams have the necessary technological insights to advance mission concepts effectively.

title: Evolution of Linear Perturbations under Time-Dependent Hubble Friction I: SR-USR-SR Inflation
summary: In this paper, we revisit the linear perturbation (including the comoving curvature perturbation and field perturbation) dynamics in the SR-USR-SR inflation with instantaneous transitions. Using the junction method and asymptotic expansions of Hankel functions, we derive accurate asymptotic expressions for the time evolution of mode functions and the resulting power spectrum, based on three systematic rules for identifying the dominant terms across transitions. Our results reveal that a finite dip of the final power spectrum arises from the cancellation between two growing modes within the linear perturbation theory, rather than between constant and growing terms as previously suggested. We also provide analytical descriptions of the amplitude enhancement and oscillatory features in the linear power spectrum, in agreement with numerical computations. These simple, tractable formulas not only facilitate theoretical calculations but also yield testable predictions for future CMB observations.

AI.tldr: The paper revisits linear perturbation dynamics in SR-USR-SR inflation, using the junction method and Hankel functions to derive accurate power spectrum expressions. It identifies that a power spectrum dip stems from cancellation between two growing modes, not constant-growing terms. Analytical formulas explain amplitude enhancement and oscillations, matching numerical results and offering testable CMB predictions.
AI.motivation: To accurately model the dynamics of linear perturbations during phased inflationary periods (SR-USR-SR) with sharp transitions, addressing previous assumptions about power spectrum features and providing tools for theoretical predictions and observational tests.
AI.method: Applied the junction method with Hankel function asymptotic expansions to analyze mode function evolution across three inflationary phases. Established three rules for tracking dominant terms through transitions, leading to asymptotic power spectrum expressions.
AI.result: Demonstrated that the power spectrum dip arises from growing mode cancellation within linear theory. Quantified amplitude enhancements and oscillations analytically, validated against numerical simulations. Derived concise formulas useful for CMB research.
AI.conclusion: Improved understanding of perturbation behavior across inflationary transitions offers precise tools for theoretical calculation and observational analysis, enhancing potential detections of inflationary features in future CMB data.

title: Constraints on GRB Jet Properties from IceCube Upper Limits: Insights from GRB 221009A and GRB 240825A
summary: The IceCube neutrino telescope has provided upper limits on neutrino emission from gamma ray bursts. These constraints provided by the IceCube detector have been instrumental in investigating the properties of the GRB jet and its emission models. During the prompt phase of gamma ray burst emission, intense radiation components are generated that interact with the shock-accelerated particles within the jet. We study various GRB emission models, such as the internal shock model, the photospheric models, and also include a model-independent case. Based on these models, we calculate the neutrino fluence using the photo-hadronic interaction process. We estimate the bulk Lorentz factor using the well-known correlations between prompt phase observables, which is then used to calculate the emission site for the model-dependent scenarios. For GRB 221009A, we find that a low baryon loading scenario is consistent with the IceCube upper limits; however, for GRB 240825A, a higher value of baryon loading is preferred. Also, the values of the microphysical parameters $ε_e$ and $ε_B$ for GRB 240825A are lower by factors of approximately 10 and 100, respectively, compared to those of GRB 221009A. Further, using neutrino upper limits for these two sources, we estimate the lower limits on the dissipation radius for our models. The current TeV PeV upper limits for GRB 221009A are already useful for constraining parameter space for the BPH and MPH models.

AI.tldr: The analysis of IceCube neutrino upper limits for GRB 221009A and GRB 240825A constrains emission models, favoring low baryon loading for GRB 221009A and higher parameters for GRB 240825A, while estimating dissipation radii through photo-hadronic processes.
AI.motivation: Investigate GRB jet properties and emission models using neutrino observables from IceCube, focusing on prompt phase interactions and baryon loading effects.
AI.method: Studied internal shock, photospheric models, and model-independent cases. Calculated neutrino fluence via photo-hadronic interactions. Used prompt phase observable correlations to estimate bulk Lorentz factor and emission site. Compared model predictions against IceCube upper limits for two GRBs.
AI.result: Low baryon loading fits IceCube limits for GRB 221009A; higher baryon loading needed for GRB 240825A. GRB 240825A shows lower ε_e, ε_B by factors ~10 and 100. Neutrino upper limits constrain dissipation radii and model parameters for BPH/MPH cases.
AI.conclusion: IceCube data effectively narrows parameter spaces for GRB emission models, emphasizing baryon loading's role and model-dependent constraints. Future higher-sensitivity neutrino telescopes could further test these models.

title: State-of-the-art cross sections for $t\bar{t}H$: NNLO+NNLL+EW predictions
comment: Talk at the 18th International Workshop on Top Quark Physics (Top2025), 21-26 September 2025
summary: The most precise theoretical predictions for the total cross section for the associated production of a Higgs boson with a top-antitop quark pair at the LHC, first presented in \cite{Balsach:2025tth}, are reported. The calculation combines NNLO QCD corrections that include an approximation of the two-loop virtual contribution, with soft-gluon resummation at NNLL accuracy in two independent frameworks (SCET and direct QCD), and complete NLO electroweak corrections.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the most precise theoretical predictions for Higgs boson production with a top-antitop quark pair at the LHC, combining NNLO QCD, NNLL soft-gluon resummation, and NLO electroweak corrections.
AI.motivation: To achieve higher precision in theoretical predictions for Higgs-tt̄ production at the LHC, which is crucial for testing the Standard Model and detecting new physics.
AI.method: Combination of NNLO QCD corrections with approximated two-loop virtual terms, NNLL soft-gluon resummation using SCET and direct QCD approaches, and complete NLO electroweak corrections.
AI.result: Reported the most precise theoretical predictions by integrating multiple high-order QCD, electroweak, and resummation methods.
AI.conclusion: These precise predictions enhance the sensitivity of LHC experiments to anomalous Higgs-tt̄ couplings and constrain beyond-Standard-Model physics.

title: Photometric classification of supernovae detected by the Zwicky Transient Facility using noise augmentation
summary: Modern time-domain surveys, such as the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), detect far more extragalactic transients than can be spectroscopically classified. Photometric classification offers a scalable alternative, enabling the identification of larger, fainter, and higher-redshift supernova samples suitable for applications such as Type Ia supernova (SN Ia) cosmology. We present a feature-based photometric classifier for SNe detected by ZTF, with the primary goal of constructing a photometric SN Ia sample for cosmological analyses. Our approach utilises the autoencoder architecture of ParSNIP (Boone 2021) to capture the intrinsic diversity of SN light curves. We trained the model on a spectroscopically classified ZTF SN sample, incorporating a realistic noise augmentation procedure that simulates the flux uncertainties of fainter sources. Light curve features were used to train a gradient-boosted decision tree classifier, implemented in both binary (SN Ia vs. non-Ia) and multi-class configurations. We validated our classifier on independent, fainter ZTF data with and without noise augmentation. To evaluate real-time performance, we also applied our classifier to live ZTF alerts and conducted a spectroscopic classification survey within the ePESSTO+ collaboration. We found that noise augmentation significantly improves classification performance, particularly for fainter sources. Our binary classifier achieves an SN Ia recall of (98.1 $\pm$ 0.4)%, averaged across five train-test splits. SN Ia recall exceeds 98% for events with a peak apparent magnitude up to 20 and more than 10 detections, and remains above 96% up to magnitude 20.5. Overall, 95% of sources were correctly classified in both binary and multi-class modes. Our classifier performs efficiently on real ZTF data and enables construction of a large photometric SN Ia sample for cosmology.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a photometric classifier for supernovae using ZTF data, achieving high recall for SN Ia classification, especially for fainter sources with noise augmentation.
AI.motivation: To handle the vast number of extragalactic transients detected by ZTF and enable scalable photometric classification for cosmological analysis, particularly for Type Ia supernovae.
AI.method: Uses an autoencoder-based model (ParSNIP) with noise augmentation, trained on spectroscopically classified ZTF data. A gradient-boosted decision tree classifier is applied in binary and multi-class modes.
AI.result: The binary classifier achieves 98.1% SN Ia recall with high accuracy up to magnitude 20.5. Noise augmentation improves performance for faint sources, with 95% overall correct classification.
AI.conclusion: The classifier efficiently classifies ZTF alerts, enabling large photometric SN Ia samples for cosmology, demonstrating scalability and reliability for future surveys.

title: A nearby He-rich superluminous supernova at photospheric phases
comment: 17 pages, 11 figures, submitted to A&A. Comments are welcome
summary: Aim. We present and interpret the data of the nearby hydrogen-deficient but helium-rich superluminous supernova SN~2021bnw which reached a magnitude of -20.7 at maximum luminosity in g band. Methods. We discuss the light curves and spectra of SN 2021bnw based on its spectro-photometric follow up exploiting different observational facilities. We reproduce the NIR spectrum of SN 2021bnw with TARDIS to inspect the chemical composition at late photospheric phases and identify helium features. We also use a STELLA model coupling hydrodynamics and radiation transport to constrain the physical parameters of the explosion assmunig a 56Ni+CSM scenario. Results. We suggest that SN 2021bnw was mainly powered by the interaction of the ejecta with a previously lost He-rich circumstellar material, coupled with a central power source. Conclusions. This work expands the data sample of He-rich superluminous supernovae rich (SLSNe Ib) and, assuming a single progenitor scenario, can constrain the masses and the physics of their progenitors.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the superluminous supernova SN 2021bnw, highlighting its exceptional brightness and chemical composition, powered by ejecta-CSM interaction and a central source. It uses observational data and models to support a helium-rich CSM scenario.
AI.motivation: To understand the mechanisms behind the extreme luminosity of SN 2021bnw and expand the dataset of He-rich SLSNe Ib, aiding in constraining progenitor models.
AI.method: Spectro-photometric observations, TARDIS NIR spectrum analysis for chemical insights, and STELLA hydrodynamics simulations under a 56Ni+CSM explosion model.
AI.result: SN 2021bnw's luminosity is driven by ejecta interacting with a helium-rich CSM plus a central energy source, confirming the role of CSM in powering SLSNe Ib.
AI.conclusion: This study enriches He-rich SLSN Ib data, supporting a single progenitor scenario and providing constraints on progenitor masses and physics.

title: Higher-Order Structure of Hamiltonian Truncation Effective Theory
summary: We study the Hamiltonian truncation for the two-dimensional $λφ^4$ theory within the framework of Hamiltonian truncation effective theory, where truncation artifacts are mitigated through a systematic inclusion of corrective terms organized in inverse powers of the ultraviolet energy cut-off $E_{\rm max}$. Building on the leading-order matching program, we develop two complementary extensions. First, we derive compact all-order expressions for the local matching corrections to the mass and quartic coupling by resumming infinite classes of diagrams sharing fixed topologies within the local approximation. Second, we extend the non-local sector by computing the next-to-next-to-local corrections contributing at $\mathcal{O}(E_{\rm max}^{-4})$, following a continuum-first matching procedure, in which the effective corrections are computed in infinite volume and the spatial direction is subsequently re-compactified to obtain a separable Hilbert-space basis on which the truncated operator construction is implemented. Our results show that an increasingly rich operator basis is necessary to describe the theory beyond leading order.

AI.tldr: The paper presents advanced Hamiltonian truncation methods for the 2D λφ⁴ theory, mitigating truncation errors via systematic corrective terms in inverse powers of the UV cutoff E_max. It introduces all-order local corrections for mass and coupling, extends non-local corrections to O(E_max⁻⁴), and employs a continuum-first approach to handle the effective operator basis.
AI.motivation: To address truncation artifacts in Hamiltonian truncation methods for the 2D λφ⁴ theory by systematically including higher-order corrections, improving accuracy and enabling precise theoretical predictions.
AI.method: 1) Resumming infinite local diagrams to derive all-order expressions for mass/coupling corrections. 2) Computing non-local corrections at O(E_max⁻⁴) using a continuum-first matching procedure, compactifying spatial dimensions to construct a separable Hilbert space basis.
AI.result: Showed that higher-order corrections require expanding the operator basis, achieving improved convergence and reduced dependence on E_max, demonstrating the necessity of a rich operator basis beyond leading-order.
AI.conclusion: Systematic inclusion of higher-order corrections and expanded operator bases is crucial for accurate Hamiltonian truncation studies in quantum field theories like 2D λφ⁴, paving the way for precise non-perturbative analyses.

title: An updated constraint for the Gravitational Wave Background from the Gamma-ray Pulsar Timing Array
comment: 12 pages, 5 figures. Accepted for publication in Physical Review D
summary: Fermi LAT observations of gamma-ray pulsars can be used to build a pulsar timing array (PTA) experiment to search for gravitational wave (GW) signals at nanohertz frequencies. At those frequencies, the dominant signal is expected to be a stochastic gravitational wave background (GWB) produced by the incoherent superposition of the quasi-monochromatic GW emissions from a population of supermassive black hole binaries. While the radio PTAs have recently announced compelling evidence for a GWB signal with a power law spectrum of strain amplitude $\approx2-3\times10^{-15}$ (at the frequency of $1 {\rm yr}^{-1}$), in 2022 an analysis of $12.5$ years of Fermi data for 35 pulsars led to an upper limit of $1\times10^{-14}$ for the GWB amplitude. The analysis was carried out on times-of-arrival (TOAs) obtained by folding from six months up to one year of photon observations. A photon-by-photon approach was also tested to infer constraints on the GWB amplitude from individual pulsars, but without accounting for the cross-pulsar correlations that a GWB would induce. Here, we reanalyse the same dataset using a regularized likelihood method that correctly models cross-pulsar correlations directly from the photons, while additionally marginalising over the uncertain pulse profile shape. While the two methods are not expected to have significant differences in sensitivity, we prove through simulations of gamma-ray PTA datasets that the photon-by-photon method for GWB recoveries is, statistically, more robust. The resulting upper limit obtained for the GWB strain amplitude is $1.2\times10^{-14}$, indicating that the improved method yields a consistent result with the previous analyses.

AI.tldr: The study uses Fermi LAT gamma-ray pulsar data to search for nanohertz gravitational waves, employing a new photon-by-photon method with cross-pulsar correlations, resulting in a GWB strain amplitude upper limit of 1.2×10^-14, consistent with prior analyses.
AI.motivation: To improve the sensitivity of pulsar timing arrays (PTAs) for detecting gravitational wave backgrounds (GWB) by addressing limitations in previous methods that didn't account for cross-pulsar correlations and pulse profile uncertainties.
AI.method: Reanalysis of 12.5 years of Fermi data using a regularized likelihood method that incorporates cross-pulsar correlations derived directly from photon data and accounts for uncertain pulse profiles through marginalization.
AI.result: Obtained a GWB strain amplitude upper limit of 1.2×10^-14, consistent with prior upper limit of 1×10^-14, while demonstrating that photon-by-photon methods are statistically more robust for GWB recovery.
AI.conclusion: The new method validates previous results and enhances confidence in gamma-ray PTA analyses by correctly modeling cross-pulsar effects, though the detected upper limit remains above radio PTA-reported GWB levels.

title: Rotating Synchrotron Radiation (RoSyRa): photon emission from magnetized and rotating quark-gluon plasma
summary: This paper investigates the production of non-prompt photons originating from rotating synchrotron radiation (RoSyRa), specifically the emission of photons by a rigidly rotating quark-gluon plasma in thermal equilibrium, in the presence of an external magnetic field. We compute the non-prompt photon spectrum and its elliptic flow ($v_2$) at mid-rapidity. In particular, we investigate the finite volume effects. We find that at low transverse momentum, the magnetic field induces a significant $v_2$, while the plasma rotation boosts the synchrotron radiation of negatively charged quarks. These effects account for both the observed excess of direct photons and their elliptic flow, contributing to the resolution of the "direct photon puzzle".

AI.tldr: This paper examines non-prompt photon production from rotating quark-gluon plasma in a magnetic field, calculating photon spectra and elliptic flow $v_2$ to address the direct photon puzzle.
AI.motivation: To resolve the direct photon puzzle by explaining excess direct photons and their elliptic flow through synchrotron radiation mechanisms in rotating, magnetized quark-gluon plasma.
AI.method: Computed non-prompt photon spectrum and $v_2$ values at mid-rapidity, considering finite volume effects of a rotating quark-gluon plasma in thermal equilibrium under external magnetic fields.
AI.result: Magnetic field induces significant $v_2$ at low transverse momentum; plasma rotation enhances synchrotron radiation from negatively charged quarks, accounting for observed photon excess and flow
AI.conclusion: These findings provide a plausible mechanism to explain experimental direct photon excess and their elliptic flow, contributing to resolving the long-standing direct photon puzzle in heavy-ion collisions.

title: $\texttt{GPUmonty}$: A GPU-accelerated relativistic Monte Carlo radiative transfer code
comment: 12 pages, 6 figures and 1 table. Comments are welcome! Submitted to ApJ
summary: We introduce $\texttt{GPUmonty}$, a CUDA/C-based Monte Carlo radiative transfer code accelerated using graphics processing units (GPUs). $\texttt{GPUmonty}$ derives from the CPU-based code $\texttt{grmonty}$ and offloads the most computationally expensive stages of the calculation -- superphoton generation, sampling, tracking, and scattering -- to the GPU. Whereas $\texttt{grmonty}$ handles photons sequentially, $\texttt{GPUmonty}$ processes large numbers of superphotons concurrently, leveraging the single-instruction, multiple-thread (SIMT) execution model of modern GPUs. Benchmarks demonstrate a speedup of about $12\times$ relative to the original CPU implementation on a single GPU, with runtime limited primarily by register pressure rather than compute or memory bandwidth saturation. We validate the implementation through analytic tests for a optically thin synchrotron sphere, as well as comparisons with $\texttt{igrmonty}$ for scattering synchrotron sphere and GRMHD simulation data. Relative errors remain below a percent level and convergence is consistent with the expected $N_{\rm s}^{-1/2}$ Monte Carlo scaling. By significantly reducing computational costs, GPUmonty enables the extensive parameter space surveys and faster spectra modeling required to interpret horizon-scale observations of supermassive black holes. $\texttt{GPUmonty}$ is publicly available under the GNU General Public License.

title: Constraining ALP-Meson overlaps from $Kπ$ form factors
summary: We present the first constraints on the overlaps between an Axion-like particle (ALP) and the $π^0$ and $η$ mesons from the analysis of the distortions to the $\langle K|\overline{s}γ^μu | π\rangle$ form factors. We demonstrate that these distortions can be tightly constrained by combining data from $τ^-\to π^0 K^-ν$ and $K^+\to π^0\ell^+ν$ decays, and go on to map the constraints to the ALP-meson overlaps. We establish that, in general, the ALP-meson and meson-ALP overlaps are different due to the presence of ALP-quark derivative couplings in the UV Lagrangian, and need to be treated separately. Using lattice results and BaBar, Belle, and NA48/2 data, we obtain exclusion limits on the overlaps and give projections for Belle II. Our techniques are independent of the branching ratios of the ALP, hence, robust against ALP decay channel assumptions. For masses of the ALP below 1 GeV, the bounds on the effective scale of the ALP physics extend to $\mathcal{O}$(TeV) for restricted regions of the parameter space for the ALP-$π$ and $π$-ALP overlaps. On the other hand, these bounds persist for extended regions of the parameter space for ALP-$η$ and $η$-ALP overlaps.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the first constraints on overlaps between Axion-like particles (ALP) and π⁰/η mesons using form factor distortions from tau and K decays. Bounds on ALP-meson interactions reach TeV scales for certain parameter regions.
AI.motivation: To establish constraints on ALP interactions with mesons without relying on ALP decay assumptions, addressing previous gaps in understanding ALP-meson couplings through derivative couplings.
AI.method: Combined analysis of τ⁻ → π⁰K⁻ν and K⁺ → π⁰ℓ⁺ν decay data, using lattice QCD results and experimental data from BaBar, Belle, and NA48/2 collaborations. Differentiates ALP-meson and meson-ALP overlaps due to UV Lagrangian's derivative couplings.
AI.result: Derived exclusion limits for ALP overlaps with π⁰/η mesons. For ALP masses below 1 GeV, effective scale bounds reach ~TeV in specific parameter regions, especially pronounced for η-related overlaps which show extended validity areas.
AI.conclusion: The method provides robust constraints independent of ALP branching ratios. Belle II has potential for enhanced projections, advancing knowledge of ALP-meson interactions in beyond-standard-model physics.

title: Profiling systematic uncertainties in Simulation-Based Inference with Factorizable Normalizing Flows
summary: Unbinned likelihood fits aim at maximizing the information one can extract from experimental data, yet their application in realistic statistical analyses is often hindered by the computational cost of profiling systematic uncertainties. Additionally, current machine learning-based inference methods are typically limited to estimating scalar parameters in a multidimensional space rather than full differential distributions. We propose a general framework for Simulation-Based Inference (SBI) that efficiently profiles nuisance parameters while measuring multivariate Distributions of Interest (DoI), defined as learnable invertible transformations of the feature space. We introduce Factorizable Normalizing Flows to model systematic variations as parametric deformations of a nominal density, preserving tractability without combinatorial explosion. Crucially, we develop an amortized training strategy that learns the conditional dependence of the DoI on nuisance parameters in a single optimization process, bypassing the need for repetitive training during the likelihood scan. This allows for the simultaneous extraction of the underlying distribution and the robust profiling of nuisances. The method is validated on a synthetic dataset emulating a high-energy physics measurement with multiple systematic sources, demonstrating its potential for unbinned, functional measurements in complex analyses.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a new Simulation-Based Inference (SBI) framework that efficiently profiles nuisance parameters while measuring multivariate distributions by using Factorizable Normalizing Flows and amortized training, validated on a synthetic high-energy physics dataset.
AI.motivation: Traditional unbinned likelihood methods are computationally expensive for profiling systematic uncertainties, and existing ML methods are limited to scalar parameters rather than full distributions.
AI.method: The framework uses Factorizable Normalizing Flows to model systematic variations as parametric deformations of a nominal density, allowing for tractable computation. An amortized training strategy learns the conditional dependence of the DoI on nuisance parameters in a single optimization step.
AI.result: The method successfully validates on a synthetic high-energy physics dataset with multiple systematic sources, enabling simultaneous extraction of distributions and nuisance parameters without repetitive training.
AI.conclusion: This approach advances unbinned likelihood analyses by addressing computational challenges and extending ML inference capabilities to functional measurements in complex analyses.

title: Addressing the Hubble tension with Sterile Neutrino Dark Matter
comment: 8 pages, 5 captioned figures, Comments are welcome
summary: One of the promising dark matter (DM) candidates is a keV scale sterile neutrino. In the early universe the observed relic of the sterile neutrino DM is generated via the \textit{Dodelson-Widrow} mechanism. However, this production scenario is severely constraint by various astrophysical observations. Many non-standard interactions between active ($ν_a$) and sterile ($ν_s$) neutrino have been proposed to evade these astrophysical bounds. Here, we study sterile neutrino in the context of a mass-varying scenario by coupling both active and sterile neutrino to a scalar field. This novel mechanism opens up a new parameter space that generates the observed DM relic and alleviates the \textit{Hubble tension}. We find that the resulting parameter space can be fully probed by future X-ray missions.

AI.conclusion: A scalar-field-coupled sterile neutrino model offers a viable dark matter candidate, alleviating both astrophysical constraints and the Hubble tension, with future experiments poised to validate or refute this framework.
